speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier. Seest thou not the air of the court in these enfoldings? Hath not my gait in it the measure of the court? Receives not thy nose court-odor from me? Reflect I not on thy baseness court-contempt? Think’st thou, for that I insinuate, that toze from thee thy business, I am therefore no courtier? I am courtier cap-a-pe, and one that will either push on or pluck back thy business there; whereupon I command thee to open thy affair.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: My business, sir, is to the King.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: What advocate hast thou to him?

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: I know not, and’t like you.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Advocate’s the court-word for a pheasant. Say you have none.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: None, sir; I have no pheasant cock, nor hen.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: How blessed are we that are not simple men!
Yet nature might have made me as these are,
Therefore I will not disdain.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: This cannot be but a great courtier.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: His garments are rich, but he wears them not handsomely.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: He seems to be the more noble in being fantastical. A great man, I’ll warrant; I know by the picking on ’s teeth.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: The fardel there? What’s i’ th’ fardel? Wherefore that box?

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: Sir, there lies such secrets in this fardel and box, which none must know but the King, and which he shall know within this hour, if I may come to th’ speech of him.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: Age, thou hast lost thy labor.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: Why, sir?

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: The King is not at the palace. He is gone aboard a new ship to purge melancholy and air himself; for if thou be’st capable of things serious, thou must know the King is full of grief.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: So ’tis said, sir—about his son, that should have married a shepherd’s daughter.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: If that shepherd be not in hand-fast, let him fly. The curses he shall have, the tortures he shall feel, will break the back of man, the heart of monster.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Think you so, sir?

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: Not he alone shall suffer what wit can make heavy and vengeance bitter; but those that are germane to him (though remov’d fifty times) shall all come under the hangman; which though it be great pity, yet it is necessary. An old sheep-whistling rogue, a ram-tender, to offer to have his daughter come into grace! Some say he shall be ston’d; but that death is too soft for him, say I. Draw our throne into a sheep-cote!—all deaths are too few, the sharpest too easy.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Has the old man e’er a son, sir, do you hear, and’t like you, sir?

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: He has a son, who shall be flay’d alive; then ’nointed over with honey, set on the head of a wasp’s nest; then stand till he be three quarters and a dram dead; then recover’d again with aqua-vitae or some other hot infusion; then, raw as he is (and in the hottest day prognostication proclaims), shall he be set against a brick-wall, the sun looking with a southward eye upon him, where he is to behold him with flies blown to death. But what talk we of these traitorly rascals, whose miseries are to be smil’d at, their offenses being so capital? Tell me (for you seem to be honest plain men) what you have to the King. Being something gently consider’d, I’ll bring you where he is aboard, tender your persons to his presence, whisper him in your behalfs; and if it be in man besides the King to effect your suits, here is man shall do it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: He seems to be of great authority. Close with him, give him gold; and though authority be a stubborn bear, yet he is oft led by the nose with gold. Show the inside of your purse to the outside of his hand, and no more ado. Remember “ston’d,” and “flay’d alive.”

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: And’t please you, sir, to undertake the business for us, here is that gold I have. I’ll make it as much more, and leave this young man in pawn till I bring it you.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: After I have done what I promis’d?

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: Ay, sir.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: Well, give me the moi’ty. Are you a party in this business?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: In some sort, sir; but though my case be a pitiful one, I hope I shall not be flay’d out of it.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: O, that’s the case of the shepherd’s son. Hang him, he’ll be made an example.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Comfort, good comfort! We must to the King, and show our strange sights. He must know ’tis none of your daughter, nor my sister; we are gone else. Sir, I will give you as much as this old man does when the business is perform’d, and remain (as he says) your pawn till it be brought you.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: I will trust you. Walk before toward the sea-side, go on the right hand, I will but look upon the hedge, and follow you.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: We are bless’d in this man, as I may say, even bless’d.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: Let’s before, as he bids us. He was provided to do us good.

scene.scenelocation: Sicily. A room in the palace of Leontes.

stagedir.dir: Enter Leontes, Cleomines, Dion, Paulina, Servants.

scene.line: Care not for issue,
The crown will find an heir. Great Alexander
Left his to th’ worthiest; so his successor
Was like to be the best.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Good Paulina,
Who hast the memory of Hermione,
I know, in honor, O, that ever I
Had squar’d me to thy counsel! Then, even now,
I might have look’d upon my queen’s full eyes,
Have taken treasure from her lips—

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: And left them
More rich for what they yielded.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Thou speak’st truth:
No more such wives, therefore no wife. One worse,
And better us’d, would make her sainted spirit
Again possess her corpse, and on this stage
(Where we offenders now) appear soul-vex’d,
And begin, “Why to me—?”

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: Had she such power,
She had just cause.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: She had, and would incense me
To murder her I married.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: I should so:
Were I the ghost that walk’d, I’ld bid you mark
Her eye, and tell me for what dull part in’t
You chose her; then I’ld shriek, that even your ears
Should rift to hear me, and the words that follow’d
Should be “Remember mine.”

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Stars, stars,
And all eyes else dead coals! Fear thou no wife;
I’ll have no wife, Paulina.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: Will you swear
Never to marry but by my free leave?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Never, Paulina, so be bless’d my spirit!

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: Then, good my lords, bear witness to his oath.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: You tempt him overmuch.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: Unless another,
As like Hermione as is her picture,
Affront his eye.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Good madam—

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: I have done.
Yet if my lord will marry—if you will, sir,
No remedy but you will—give me the office
To choose you a queen. She shall not be so young
As was your former, but she shall be such
As (walk’d your first queen’s ghost) it should take joy
To see her in your arms.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: My true Paulina,
We shall not marry till thou bid’st us.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: That
Shall be when your first queen’s again in breath;
Never till then.

scene.line: Still, ’tis strange
He thus should steal upon us.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: Had our prince,
Jewel of children, seen this hour, he had pair’d
Well with this lord; there was not full a month
Between their births.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Prithee no more; cease. Thou know’st
He dies to me again when talk’d of. Sure
When I shall see this gentleman, thy speeches
Will bring me to consider that which may
Unfurnish me of reason. They are come.

stagedir.dir: Enter Florizel, Perdita, Cleomines, and others.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Most noble sir,
That which I shall report will bear no credit,
Were not the proof so nigh. Please you, great sir,
Bohemia greets you from himself by me;
Desires you to attach his son, who has
(His dignity and duty both cast off)
Fled from his father, from his hopes, and with
A shepherd’s daughter.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Where’s Bohemia? Speak.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Here, in your city; I now came from him.
I speak amazedly, and it becomes
My marvel and my message. To your court
Whiles he was hast’ning (in the chase, it seems,
Of this fair couple), meets he on the way
The father of this seeming lady, and
Her brother, having both their country quitted
With this young prince.

speech.speaker: FLO.
speech.line: Camillo has betray’d me;
Whose honor and whose honesty till now
Endur’d all weathers.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Lay’t so to his charge:
He’s with the King your father.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Who? Camillo?

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Camillo, sir; I spake with him; who now
Has these poor men in question. Never saw I
Wretches so quake: they kneel, they kiss the earth;
Forswear themselves as often as they speak.
Bohemia stops his ears, and threatens them
With divers deaths in death.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: O my poor father!
The heaven sets spies upon us, will not have
Our contract celebrated.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: You are married?

speech.speaker: FLO.
speech.line: We are not, sir, nor are we like to be.
The stars, I see, will kiss the valleys first;
The odds for high and low’s alike.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: My lord,
Is this the daughter of a king?

speech.speaker: FLO.
speech.line: She is,
When once she is my wife.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: That “once,” I see, by your good father’s speed,
Will come on very slowly. I am sorry,
Most sorry, you have broken from his liking,
Where you were tied in duty; and as sorry
Your choice is not so rich in worth as beauty,
That you might well enjoy her.

speech.speaker: FLO.
speech.line: Dear, look up.
Though Fortune, visible an enemy,
Should chase us with my father, pow’r no jot
Hath she to change our loves. Beseech you, sir,
Remember since you ow’d no more to time
Than I do now. With thought of such affections,
Step forth mine advocate. At your request
My father will grant precious things as trifles.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Would he do so, I’ld beg your precious mistress,
Which he counts but a trifle.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: Sir, my liege,
Your eye hath too much youth in’t. Not a month
’Fore your queen died, she was more worth such gazes
Than what you look on now.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I thought of her,
Even in these looks I made.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: Beseech you, sir, were you present at this relation?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: I was by at the opening of the fardel, heard the old shepherd deliver the manner how he found it; whereupon, after a little amazedness, we were all commanded out of the chamber; only this, methought, I heard the shepherd say, he found the child.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: I would most gladly know the issue of it.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: I make a broken delivery of the business; but the changes I perceiv’d in the King and Camillo were very notes of admiration. They seem’d almost, with staring on one another, to tear the cases of their eyes. There was speech in their dumbness, language in their very gesture; they look’d as they had heard of a world ransom’d, or one destroy’d. A notable passion of wonder appear’d in them; but the wisest beholder, that knew no more but seeing, could not say if th’ importance were joy or sorrow; but in the extremity of the one, it must needs be.

Here comes the Lady Paulina’s steward, he can deliver you more. How goes it now, sir? This news, which is call’d true, is so like an old tale, that the verity of it is in strong suspicion. Has the King found his heir?

speech.speaker: 3. GENT.
speech.line: Most true, if ever truth were pregnant by circumstance. That which you hear you’ll swear you see, there is such unity in the proofs. The mantle of Queen Hermione’s; her jewel about the neck of it; the letters of Antigonus found with it, which they know to be his character; the majesty of the creature in resemblance of the mother; the affection of nobleness which nature shows above her breeding; and many other evidences proclaim her, with all certainty, to be the King’s daughter. Did you see the meeting of the two kings?

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: 3. GENT.
speech.line: Then have you lost a sight which was to be seen, cannot be spoken of. There might you have beheld one joy crown another, so and in such manner that it seem’d sorrow wept to take leave of them, for their joy waded in tears. There was casting up of eyes, holding up of hands, with countenance of such distraction that they were to be known by garment, not by favor. Our king, being ready to leap out of himself for joy of his found daughter, as if that joy were now become a loss, cries, “O, thy mother, thy mother!”; then asks Bohemia forgiveness; then embraces his son-in-law; then again worries he his daughter with clipping her. Now he thanks the old shepherd, which stands by like a weather-bitten conduit of many kings’ reigns. I never heard of such another encounter, which lames report to follow it, and undoes description to do it.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: What, pray you, became of Antigonus, that carried hence the child?

speech.speaker: 3. GENT.
speech.line: Like an old tale still, which will have matter to rehearse, though credit be asleep and not an ear open: he was torn to pieces with a bear. This avouches the shepherd’s son, who has not only his innocence (which seems much) to justify him, but a handkerchief and rings of his that Paulina knows.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: What became of his bark and his followers?

speech.speaker: 3. GENT.
speech.line: Wrack’d the same instant of their master’s death, and in the view of the shepherd; so that all the instruments which aided to expose the child were even then lost when it was found. But O, the noble combat that ’twixt joy and sorrow was fought in Paulina! She had one eye declin’d for the loss of her husband, another elevated that the oracle was fulfill’d. She lifted the Princess from the earth, and so locks her in embracing, as if she would pin her to her heart, that she might no more be in danger of losing.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: The dignity of this act was worth the audience of kings and princes, for by such was it acted.

speech.speaker: 3. GENT.
speech.line: One of the prettiest touches of all, and that which angled for mine eyes (caught the water though not the fish), was when, at the relation of the Queen’s death (with the manner how she came to’t bravely confess’d and lamented by the King), how attentiveness wounded his daughter, till (from one sign of dolor to another) she did (with an “Alas!”), I would fain say, bleed tears; for I am sure my heart wept blood. Who was most marble there chang’d color; some swounded, all sorrow’d. If all the world could have seen’t, the woe had been universal.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Are they return’d to the court?

speech.speaker: 3. GENT.
speech.line: No. The Princess hearing of her mother’s statue, which is in the keeping of Paulina—a piece many years in doing and now newly perform’d by that rare Italian master, Julio Romano, who, had he himself eternity and could put breath into his work, would beguile Nature of her custom, so perfectly he is her ape. He so near to Hermione hath done Hermione that they say one would speak to her and stand in hope of answer. Thither with all greediness of affection are they gone, and there they intend to sup.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: I thought she had some great matter there in hand, for she hath privately twice or thrice a day, ever since the death of Hermione, visited that remov’d house. Shall we thither, and with our company piece the rejoicing?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Who would be thence that has the benefit of access? Every wink of an eye some new grace will be born. Our absence makes us unthrifty to our knowledge. Let’s along.
Here come those I have done good to against my will, and already appearing in the blossoms of their fortune.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: Come, boy, I am past more children, but thy sons and daughters will be all gentlemen born.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: You are well met, sir. You denied to fight with me this other day, because I was no gentleman born. See you these clothes? Say you see them not and think me still no gentleman born. You were best say these robes are not gentlemen born. Give me the lie, do; and try whether I am not now a gentleman born.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: I know you are now, sir, a gentleman born.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay, and have been so any time these four hours.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: And so have I, boy.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: So you have. But I was a gentleman born before my father; for the King’s son took me by the hand, and call’d me brother; and then the two kings call’d my father brother; and then the Prince, my brother, and the Princess, my sister, call’d my father father; and so we wept; and there was the first gentleman-like tears that ever we shed.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: We may live, son, to shed many more.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay; or else ’twere hard luck, being in so preposterous estate as we are.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: I humbly beseech you, sir, to pardon me all the faults I have committed to your worship, and to give me your good report to the Prince my master.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we are gentlemen.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Thou wilt amend thy life?

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: Ay, and it like your good worship.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Give me thy hand: I will swear to the Prince thou art as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: You may say it, but not swear it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Not swear it, now I am a gentleman? Let boors and franklins say it, I’ll swear it.

speech.speaker: SHEP.
speech.line: How if it be false, son?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: If it be ne’er so false, a true gentleman may swear it in the behalf of his friend; and I’ll swear to the Prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands, and that thou wilt not be drunk; but I know thou art no tall fellow of thy hands, and that thou wilt be drunk; but I’ll swear it, and I would thou wouldst be a tall fellow of thy hands.

speech.speaker: AUT.
speech.line: I will prove so, sir, to my power.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay, by any means prove a tall fellow. If I do not wonder how thou dar’st venture to be drunk, not being a tall fellow, trust me not. Hark, the kings and the princes, our kindred, are going to see the Queen’s picture. Come, follow us; we’ll be thy good masters.

stagedir.dir: Enter Leontes, Polixenes, Florizel, Perdita, Camillo, Paulina, Lords, etc.

scene.line: ’Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach;
Strike all that look upon with marvel. Come;
I’ll fill your grave up. Stir; nay, come away;
Bequeath to death your numbness; for from him
Dear life redeems you. You perceive she stirs.
Start not; her actions shall be holy, as
You hear my spell is lawful. Do not shun her
Until you see her die again, for then
You kill her double. Nay, present your hand.
When she was young, you woo’d her; now, in age,
Is she become the suitor?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: O, she’s warm!
If this be magic, let it be an art
Lawful as eating.

speech.speaker: POL.
speech.line: She embraces him.

speech.speaker: CAM.
speech.line: She hangs about his neck.
If she pertain to life let her speak too.

speech.speaker: POL.
speech.line: Ay, and make it manifest where she has liv’d,
Or how stol’n from the dead.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: That she is living,
Were it but told you, should be hooted at
Like an old tale; but it appears she lives,
Though yet she speak not. Mark a little while.
Please you to interpose, fair madam, kneel,
And pray your mother’s blessing. Turn, good lady,
Our Perdita is found.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: You gods, look down
And from your sacred vials pour your graces
Upon my daughter’s head! Tell me, mine own,
Where hast thou been preserv’d? Where liv’d? How found
Thy father’s court? For thou shalt hear that I,
Knowing by Paulina that the oracle
Gave hope thou wast in being, have preserv’d
Myself to see the issue.

speech.speaker: PAUL.
speech.line: There’s time enough for that;
Least they desire (upon this push) to trouble
Your joys with like relation. Go together,
You precious winners all; your exultation
Partake to every one. I, an old turtle,
Will wing me to some wither’d bough, and there
My mate (that’s never to be found again)
Lament till I am lost.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: O, peace, Paulina!
Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent,
As I by thine a wife: this is a match,
And made between ’s by vows. Thou hast found mine,
But how, is to be question’d; for I saw her
(As I thought) dead; and have (in vain) said many
A prayer upon her grave. I’ll not seek far
(For him, I partly know his mind) to find thee
An honorable husband. Come, Camillo,
And take her by the hand, whose worth and honesty
Is richly noted; and here justified
By us, a pair of kings. Let’s from this place.
What? Look upon my brother. Both your pardons,
That e’er I put between your holy looks
My ill suspicion. This’ your son-in-law,
And son unto the King, whom heavens directing
Is troth-plight to your daughter. Good Paulina,
Lead us from hence, where we may leisurely
Each one demand, and answer to his part
Perform’d in this wide gap of time, since first
We were dissever’d. Hastily lead away.
